title: Will the UAE’s Customer Happiness Index be higher for 2020 as compared to 2019?
preds:
The UAE use a survey to produce a composite indicator to measure the resident’s satisfaction of their living standards, that include experiences with Government Departments and perspectives on income level, life expectancy, anti-corruption and freedom to make personal choices. 
Emiratis make up 20% of the population which means most residents choose to live and work there.
There is no income tax, homelessness and a safe environment with very low crime rate.
The Governments Happiness Agenda comprises of the following criteria that are Discover (needs); Change (policies); Educate (create awareness); Measure.
For example, the 2019 survey had the following:- ‘Dubai Electricity and Water Authority was ranked first in the 2019 Government of Dubai Customer Happiness and Mystery Shopper Index with a score of 90.1%. The Roads and Transport Authority (89.3%) came second and Dubai Health Authority (88.6%) came third. The lowest-performing entities in the Index were Dubai Customs and Dubai Culture (81.8% each), Dubai Land Department (79.6%) and the Dubai Public Prosecution (77.8%)’. The UAE Governments handling of the Covid-19 has been successful (so far) and the lockdowns are being eased that would prove popular and an indication of happiness (compared to other countries).

The more I look at this, the more I regret forecasting it. This is a rather subjective and obscure question, and I think @sebawi has the most salient and cogent assessment of the situation of all: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1046503 This is a strong candidate for a 0/50/100% decision. It either will happen or won't, I don't think a 75% yes makes sense here. I don't know how aggressive I'm willing to be, and undoubtedly, my mood will change... but UAE has the means to make this happen, and if it is important to them, then they will. I presume it is a legitimate process, although I wouldn't rule out the (laughably) questionable nature of improving something as nebulous as a Customer Happiness Index. I'm reminded of the question about whether Putin will be able to amend the Russian constitution and his term limits.
That said, I'll play ball... but I feel this is an all or nothing scenario.
Still, the romantic side of me whispers in my ear "pssst, anything's popsicle" and I say, "yes yes, I don't actually believe it is a 100% certainty." 
And again, I wish I had sat this one out. C'est la vie.
Still feels likely, but scaling back to respond to the consensus.
Sorry Prince, happiness level will inevitably decline in 2020, but its always good to set your goals high.

There are a set of issues that complicate the forecast due to a lack of information on how the index is constructed (- at least I couldn't find it, if you have found more information, please comment). We don't know ... 1. ... what exact questions are asked.
2. ... how these questions are translated into scales.
3. ... how questions are ultimately weighted. That means, there is a lot of uncertainty on what the index is ought to measure and how the index is constructed. From the 2019 Customer Happiness Index we know that 16 different categories are used that each refer to a specific government service [1]. Construction of the index takes place "through integrated methodological studies [... ] tailored to suit the UAE experience and directives in providing government services" [1] - possibly referring to a type of "integrated modification methodology" [2]. It doesn't change the fact, however, that we don't have enough information to make a good judgment.  What does that leave us with? First of all, it seems the most fruitful to think about those services with the highest potential for improvement ... but I don't know enough about the different agencies and the lack of information on those areas that have performed the best and the worst makes it hard to get a grasp where potential improvements might happen. That said, there only remains the option to rely on the announcements of those in power. Do we trust that them setting ambitious goals is enough to actually see improvements? Do the announcements of the Dubai Crown Prince mean they are confident in reaching a better outcome - possibly through the provision of resources and competent and sufficient personnel [3]? Does his personal oversight [4] mean actual improvements have to happen - or at least be evaluated to be there? And what does the outbreak of COVID-19 mean for the outcome - less resources, less improvements? Currently, I'm confident that they'll pull it off and we'll see a higher value.
